Intrusion.definition: the entry at common law of a stranger after a particular estate of freehold is determined before the person who holds it in remainder or reversion has taken possession b
Intrusion.origin: [the Fourth Amendment demands that the showing of justification match the degree of " Berger v. New York , 388 U.S. 41 (1968)"]

1 a.definition: the entry at common law of a stranger after a particular estate of freehold is determined before the person who holds it in remainder or reversion has taken possession

sub_terms.b: the act of wrongfully entering upon, seizing, or taking possession of the property of another

2.definition: a trespassing on or encroachment upon something (as a right) [the Fourth Amendment demands that the showing of justification match the degree of ", 388 U.S. 41 (1968)"]
